question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form "\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct."
Find
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]
inference:
Let $A_k = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & k \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.
Then the product is
\begin{align*} A_1 A_3 A_5 \dotsm A_{99} &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1+3+5+\dots+99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \frac{(1+99)(50)}{2} \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \frac{100 \cdot 50}{2} \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \end{align*} 
The sum of the odd integers from 1 to 99 is $\frac{(99+1)}{2} \cdot \frac{99-1}{2} + \frac{99+1}{2} = 50(99+1)/2 = 50(100)/2 = 2500$.
Thus, the product is $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.

\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}
I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
More generally,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]

question:

Then the product is
\begin{align*} A_1 A_3 A_5 \dotsm A_{99} &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1+3+5+\dots+99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \frac{(1+99)(50)}{2} \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & \frac{100 \cdot 50}{2} \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \end{align*} 
The sum of the odd integers from 1 to 99 is $\frac{(99+1)}{2} \cdot \frac{99-1}{2} + \frac{99+1}{2} = 50(99+1)/2 = 50(100)/2 = 2500$.
Thus, the product is $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.

I hope it is correct.

ground_truth:
More generally,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a + b \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \dotsm \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 + 3 + 5 + \dots + 99 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2500 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
